msgSnippet: Cédric, Following up on what you said, I see test as a form of meta-data, but since it is only there by convention the compiler can t help you if you spell
messageBody:
Cédric,

Following up on what you said, I see "test" as a form of meta-data, but
since it is only there by convention the compiler can't help you if you
spell "tset" instead. Annotations are native meta-data so the IDE can help
more. OTOH, I can see how switching isn't trivial. After you've typed "test"
the first thousand times, it becomes almost a reflex.

Regards,

Kent


_____

Subject: Re: [junit] Strange request: examples of "beautiful" test code



On 11/28/06, Stephen Smith <steve@stephen-
<mailto:steve%40stephen-smith.co.uk> smith.co.uk> wrote:
>
>
> I guess my skepticism of annotations when JSE5 was first released has
> unfortunately been transferred to JUnit 4 over time. Maybe I'm a bit
> stuck in my ways after writing so many JUnit 3.x test cases down the
> years?

When you write a test method that starts with "test", you are actually
tagging extra information to your method to indicate that it's a tag, but
you are doing it in a way that messes with your code.

You can't find a better use of annotations than that...

--
Cédric
